thread.title: Defecation accusations spice up WA campaign trail
thread.title_full: Defecation accusations spice up WA campaign trail

title: Defecation accusations spice up WA campaign trail
text:
Just over two weeks out from the election and the Premier and his Opposition counterpart were both busy touring far-flung parts of the metropolitan area - Colin Barnett to the John Forrest National Park and Mark McGowan to Henderson. 
Here's what you may have missed on Friday: Defecation claim Photo: People have been "defecating in vehicles" according to the Premier. 
Mr Barnett has long bemoaned the behaviour of anti-Roe 8 protesters, but he stepped up his criticism with an unusual accusation. 
"They [workers] have had to put up with abuse ... and - I don't like to say it - people defecating in vehicles," he said. 
Anti-Roe 8 activists were taken aback by the accusation, saying they had not seen or heard of any evidence to support it. 
Asked for more evidence of the claims, the Premier's office said a worker detailed the experience during a meeting with him yesterday. Missing in action 
The Premier pledged Liberal support for more mountain bike trails if he wins a third term, but one thing was missing from the media event announcing the policy. Photo: Mr Barnett and Health Minister John Day had no luck finding a cyclist. (ABC News: Jacob Kagi) 
Mr Barnett's office had tried to arrange for cyclists to attend, but none came. 
Keen to find riders for a vision opportunity, Mr Barnett and several aides climbed up to a nearby track to attempt to flag one passing by. 
When nobody rode past after more than five minutes waiting, they eventually gave up. One Nation casualties 
One Nation has taken the unusual step of officially disendorsing two of its candidates, just a fortnight out from the election. 
Dane Sorenson, who was standing for the party in North West Central, and Thornlie's Sandy Baraiolo have been removed from One Nation's online candidates list and had their social media pages deleted. 
Problem is, ballot papers have already been printed - so voters in these seats will still see the pair listed as One Nation candidates. 
Political analyst Peter Kennedy said the controversy "might even boost their votes". Shipbuilding promise 
Labor believes WA is missing out on defence contracts because the State Government is not advocating hard enough, and is promising a defence advocate and a Minister for Defence Issues if it wins government. 
"I want to make sure we get our fair share of defence build," Opposition Leader Mr McGowan said. 
He is also keen to lobby the US for more visits by its naval ships. 
But Liberal Commerce Minister Michael Mischin said the State Government was already effective at lobbying for defence contracts.
